dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day breaks. Hassan (50) arrives at a solitary house made adobe, in the southern deserts of Morocco, carrying a sat and a large bundle wrapped in cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks past a corral made out of branches, where severa goats bleat, and knocks on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah (40), opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Good morning Abdullah... I brought you this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the bundle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah's family is inside the house. There is a room, a small table and a simple kitchen. Yasira (38) is roasting some goat meat assisted by Yamil (16) and Zora (17), her daughters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah and his sons, Yussef (13) and Ahmed (14), are si on the floor around the small table, looking at a well- conserved .270 caliber Winchester 60 rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Abdullah) It's almost new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out several boxes of cartridges from his satchel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred cartridges...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a box and shows them one of the golden bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hunter who gave it to me said you can hit up to three kilometers away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you want for everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand dirhams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thousand dirhams? I'll give you one thousand and a goat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah and Hassan exchange a look and Hassan smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hassan and Abdullah's family are behind the house. Hassan stands with the rifle in front of a rock some twenty yard away and he turns toward Abdullah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this rifle, your sons will be able to kill plenty of jackals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He aims at the rock and pulls the trigger without holding the rifle properly. It is clear that he doesn't know how fire a weapon, and the shot cracks loudly. The rifle kick and hits him roughly in the shoulder. The bullet flies fa wide of the rock. The women laugh nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbing his shoulder, Hassan turns to Abdullah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let one of your sons shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah looks at his boys and points at the younger one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Yussef shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Hassan is about to hand Yussef the rifle, Ahmed cuts him off, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to shoot first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father and son exchange an angry glance. Hassan, without realizing it, turns and gives the rifle to Ahmed. The boy grabs the gun: it is heavier than he thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, load it like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hassan opens the chamber, inserts the bullet and then clo it. Once it is loaded, he points at the safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the safety. Push it in when you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed nods. Unsure of himself, he raises the rifle and, almost without aiming, fires. The shot kicks up dust far from the rock. His sisters laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he doesn't hit the jackals, at least he'll scare the shit out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed lowers the rifle. His father grabs it and gives it Yussef enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef grabs the rifle and loads it confidently. He lifts the rifle with ease and takes his time aiming. He seems innately skilled at the maneuver. He shoots and the bulle hits just below the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah celebrates the shot and mockingly turns to Hassa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this kid shoots a hell of a lot better than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef takes one of the goats out, ties and ropes it and gives it to Hassan. Abdullah supervises. Yasira approache and gives Abdullah a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah takes it and turns to his sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better kill at least three jackals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And make sure no one sees you with the rifle, hide it if you see someone approach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed nods.   Abdullah and Hassan go on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasira and Yamil are far from the house, cleaning some goatskins stretched out on some branches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed, with the rifle in his hands, opens the corral gate and enters to herd them out. He calls his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef, Yussef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef is squatting on the other side of the house, spyin through a crack, breathing excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zora is inside, undressing. She has a long body and her cinnamon skin is soft and clean. Every now and then she aims a complicit glance at the crack through which Yussef spying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zora turns around toward where the voice is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef is still spying.    Ahmed approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef turns around and signals for him to lower his voic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to spy on her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef pays no attention and keeps spying. Ahmed pulls hi by the shoulder and makes him lose his balance. Yussef fa on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said don't spy on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef gets up and dusts himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goats graze. Yussef and Ahmed watch them sitting on t side of a hill. They look hot and bored. They both throw stones at a small rusty can. Yussef throws one and misses Ahmed throws his and does. He draws a line in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five to two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jackal is stalking the goats.    Yussef spots it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a jackal over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed raises his head but cannot see it. Yussef points at it, but Ahmed still cannot locate it. Yussef despairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed finally spots it. He loads the rifle, but when he i about to aim, the rifle fires. The shot hits amidst the goats, lifting up a small cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, you idiot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jackal flees, terrified, while the goats scamper in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both brothers are sitting under a tree, eating bread and drinking water from a goatskin canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zora doesn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed keeps eating without turning to look at his brother

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't, but I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is between her and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both pigs. Next time I'm going to tell my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want me to stay out of it, don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef gets annoyed, stand up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers are sitting apart from each other.   Ahmed g the goats with the rifle on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while, Yussef goes to sit behind a large rock. He makes sure his brother isn't watching and he pulls his pa down to start masturbating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he is at his most concentrated, a shot rings out and startles him. He quickly pulls his pants up and another shot rings out. Yussef gets up to see what his brother is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed is aiming the rifle at a rock some two hundred yard away. He fires a third time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef runs up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed doesn't pay attention, and focuses on the rock in t distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hassan said that it could hit things three kilometers away, but it can't even reach that rock over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you don't know how to shoot. Give me the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed looks at his brother defiantly, then hands the rifl over. Yussef aims and fires. The shot echoes through the vast desert; the frightened goats scamper a few yards awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, it can't reach it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me another bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef aims and fires. The bullet hits the rock and kicks up a lot of whitish dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that's not three kilometers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed remains pensive and suddenly starts climbing to the top of the hill. Once at the top, he looks around for a moment and then calls his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef, come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef climbs the slope. Ahmed signals a road that in the distance cuts across the great desert plain, and points o a traffic sign that indicates a curve ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you the bullet can't hit that far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed loads the rifle and aims at the sign.    He fires a nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These fucking bullets aren't any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not aiming right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef points at a yellow car driving along the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you give me if I hit that car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed reloads. The empty cartridge falls to the ground. H fires again - the car keeps going. Yussef asks for the ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?    Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He also drops the used cartridge on the ground, reloads a shoots the traffic sign. He fires and nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.    Hassan's a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus approaches.    Ahmed points at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot at that one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef loads the rifle parsimoniously, shuts the chamber, raises the weapon, aims and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives on.    Ahmed turns to his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See: nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives on another three hundred yards and suddenl stops in the middle of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia (54), a maternal, Mexican woman with a pleasant fa is playing Monopoly with Debbie (4) and Mike (5). They ar both typically American kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) I won...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings and Amelia goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In English) Yes... yes sir... yes sir, Mrs. Rachel told me...I'm very sorry. How is Mrs. Susan?... No sir, don't worry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia turns to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad is calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike runs to the phone and grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi dad... dad, guess what? Today, at school, they brought some baby chickens...I held one in my hand. He was really little and he was all warm... (A beat) Dad, are you ok?...And Mariana wanted to take one home, but the teacher didn't let her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia is putting Debbie and Mike to sleep.   They are bo lying in bed. Amelia sits next to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Did you brush your teeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike shows her his teeth so she can see he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell us a story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One and then you're going to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both children nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Her entire story in Spanish) Once there was a hawk who wanted to fly higher than everyone else. He trained every day and hunted little birds so he could eat them and be strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pajaritos?     Little birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, that's what hawks eat. So, one day the hawk flew so, so high that it crashed into an airplane. It fainted and started to fall. And when it was about to hit the ground, all the birds flew toward him and saved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They saved him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and when the hawk was healthy again he went to talk to the birds and said: I want to thank you for saving me, but I can't change and I'm going to keep hunting you. The little birds answered: we don't care that you hunt us, because that's who you are. But we will always save you, because that's who we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In English) Did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia moves to turn out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia stands still beside the switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quedamos en que se iban a dormir con la luz apagada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pasa nada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared that what happened to Pat is gonna happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia sits down next to her and caresses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ti no te va a pasar eso...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat died while she was sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That only happens to some babies when they're really little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did daddy get so angry at mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't angry, he was just very sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia doesn't know what else to say. She pats Debbie's h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. I'll sit here with you, but you can't talk anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both nod and snuggle under their blankets. Amelia wa them silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia (54) sleeps. The sun is just starting to rise. A phone rings distantly. Amelia awakes. She sits up, listen intently and hears the ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs a robe from a chair beside her, puts it on and gets up to answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia enters the kitchen and answers a wall phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, it's Richard. We're going to have to be here a few more days here in Morocco than we expected and Rachel wasn't able to find anyone to take care of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister-in-law promised me to find someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, this is very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because... I told Mrs. Jones three months ago that today is my son's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, this is an emergency. Cancel your son's wedding. I'll pay for another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, everything is ready. Can't anyone come take care of the kids? It's just one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need you, Amelia... hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stops talking. We hear voices in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, we're really counting on you. I have to go. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.   Amelia stares into empty space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie (4) and Mike (5) are having breakfast while Amelia leans on the sink and looks at them, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Debbie, in Spanish) Do you want another quesadilla?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia turns around to warm up a tortilla. Mike stops eat his cereal and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many little birds did the hawk eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia turns around and sees Mike, who is truly worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In English) None, because he started to like quesadillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia strokes his hair. A car horn honks. Amelia looks out and sees a school bus parked outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the bus here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Yes, but today you're not going to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have things to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia turns around and walks out to the street. Through the door we can see her saying something to the bus drive The school bus leaves and Amelia walks back into the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Mike are watching cartoons while Amelia talks the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Both in Spanish) I just want you to take of them for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Mrs. Black is home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she won't go out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, thanks.    I'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and remains pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia and the kids walk down a street in Santa Monica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia and the kids are standing in front of a house, tal with Lucia (22), who is dressed in a black and white unif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Both in Spanish) I can't Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, it's my son's wedding. I helped you out with that thing with your boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for the day, Lucia.   I'll be back for them tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do I tell Mrs. Black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her they're your nephews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucia looks down at the blonde-haired, blue-eyed children

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right, they look just like me...with this gringa look I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia is packing the children's clothes in a small suitc Debbie and Mike, curious, watch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to see your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you're going to see my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Not very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down '88 Ford Pinto parks in front of the house and honks its horn. The front door opens and Amelia walks out carrying the small suitcase, with the two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago (24), a young Mexican with light eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Both in Spanish) Good morning Aunt Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago, surprised, looks at the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't find anyone to leave them with. Their parents aren't coming back today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why bring them, they're just going to make trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're good kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a woman who can take care of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago, I have to take them. I can't leave them with just anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you lose your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, don't tempt the fates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia opens the door for the children to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard (45), tall, thin, weathered, and Susan (38), good looking, with an athletic body, visit the impressive Casb with a group of American, French and English tourists. Mo of them are old, with a few couples in their forties or fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar (30), a man with a kind face, is the tour guide sho them around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In English, with an Arabic accent) The Berbers built these kasbahs. They made them like forts and here they would reside after finishing their caravans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard listens attentively.   Susan looks hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is beautiful, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not very enthusiastically) Yeah, yeah it's very pretty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar walks toward one end of the aisles and calls the gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'd like to show you the materials that were used to build the walls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The herd moves docile toward Anwar's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of tourists spread about a small eatery with op air tables on a dusty terrace. A bus is parked behind the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table, on one end of the terrace with views to a clu of mountains, Richard and Susan look through some menus. Richard seems at ease in this place. Susan appears to be bothered by the dust and otherness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter brings a plate and some cutlery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in broken English) You want to order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a chicken cous-cous and a Coke, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have that doesn't have fat in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan reads the menu again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the fried eggplant and a diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a regular Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter smiles and goes to place the order. Susan take out a small bottle with antibacterial gel, cleans her han and then starts wiping the plate and the cutlery thorough

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard looks at the mountain range through a pair of binoculars. He spots a hawk flying over the plains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, look: a hawk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard follows the hawk with his binoculars for a few se and then puts them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This country is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan remains silent and then turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, why did we come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean why? I thought you would like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really: why are we here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard knows that Susan's answer implies something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To forget everything, to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, sardonically gestures toward the other tourists wi her chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard sighs in disappointment. The waiter arrives with the Cokes and the food, which does not look particularly appetizing. He leaves everything on the table and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is about to pour his drink when Susan stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw out the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coke is warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you don't know what kind of water is in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs Richard's glass and tosses out the ice. Then sh does the same thing with hers. They are quiet for a momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you ever relax.    You're always stressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one stressing me out. You're why I can't relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could if you tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tried? Don't you think I tried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're never going to forgive me, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even know what I'm talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, please; we didn't come all this way just to argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan gets angry and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we didn't? Then when are we supposed to "argue"? Or are you planning on running away again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard sighs, defeated. They stop speaking and sit looki at the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tourists crowd around to board the bus. Some boys in rags approach to sell them trinkets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stilo...stilo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the tourists buy them. They come to Susan, who becomes instantly uncomfortable. She gestures with her ha to say they have no money, but the kids insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stilo...stilo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any money... I don't have any...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard takes off his binoculars and gives them to the youngest of the boys (7), who receives them with wide eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard just gets in the bus. Susan stares at the boy wit the binoculars for a moment and then gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan sits next to the window, in the middle of the bus. She looks hurt and sad. Richard walks over and sits next her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus starts. Through the window, Richard can still see the boy with the binoculars. He smiles until he sees an o boy snatch the binoculars away and push the little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives away, but Richard can't take his eyes off scene. The older boy walks away with the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives down a straight road that divides the dese

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives on. Some of the old men sleep. Susan leans her head against the window and watches the landscape scr past. Richard sits beside her silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan holds out her hand and takes Richard's, as a sign o reconciliation. He holds hers and caresses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan gets comfortable to try to sleep. She closes her ey when suddenly something smashes the window and Susan coll forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard turns to look at the punctured glass and then Sus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan doesn't answer, limp on her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard lifts her up and when he does he sees a thread of blood run down her neck. Richard yells at the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the bus, stop, my wife's been hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an indoor volleyball court with bleachers, several Jap girls play volleyball. They all compete intensely for the point. There is excitement, but everything occurs quietly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A player jumps and spikes the ball. Chieko (16), tall, beautiful, with strands of hair painted purple, volleys t ball back up. It reaches one of her teammates who sets up another to spike it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko's team wins the point. The referee, instead of whistling, lifts up a red flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players congratulate each other silently, in sign language. The only sound we can here is the parents' clap as they watch the game from the stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko's team serves. Again, the game is heated. A rival player spikes the ball, and it is barely out of bounds. However, the referee, with his red flag, calls the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko is upset and goes to argue with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In sign language) The ball was out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In sign language) No, it was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko gestures violently.   One of her teammates goes to calm her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko breaks loose and approaches the referee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not just deaf, you're blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko is furious.   She starts to make obscene gestures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach walks onto the court. He holds her to calm her down and then takes her away. Despite Chieko's violent reaction, everything is still silent. From the bleachers, Yasujiro (47), Chieko's father, dressed in a nice suit wi the tie undone, with a sad pride about him, disapproves o his daughter's actions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko sits on a bench in her underwear. She looks aggrav and absorbed in her own thoughts. Her other teammates get dressed. Two of them walk past wrapped in towels, freshly showered, and stand in front of her. They talk to each ot in sign language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have lost your temper. We lost the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault, it was the ref.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hadn't been thrown out, we would've won the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko, angry, gets up and starts to rummage through her locker. Her teammate walks over and gets her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you in a bad mood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko doesn't answer.    Teammate 2 approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's always in a bad mood because nobody's fucked her yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She caps this with an obscene gesture that bothers Chieko

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna fuck your dad to get rid of my mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teammate 1 laughs, amused. Teammate 2 gives Chieko a scor look. Chieko smiles sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasujiro drives while Chieko looks at the swarming Tokyo streets. She is wearing a skirt revealing of her long volleyball legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her fathers speaks to her in sign language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'd meet my friends from the team at Eve's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't we going to have lunch together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I told you I was going to eat with them, but you never pay attention to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasujiro shakes his head in disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother always paid attention to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't say anything else.   The traffic is chaotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss your mother too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing what I can, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't say anything else.   The traffic is chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasujiro parks his car and Chieko gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in sign language) Don't forget you have the dentist at four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko looks annoyed, and blows her father a kiss goodbye As she is about to get out of the car, Yasujiro grabs her arm. She turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In sign language) I love you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange a glance.   She nods, closes the door and l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve's is a restaurant full of t.v.'s, noise, video games. There is smoke, and people talking everywhere. Chieko mov through the crowd. A hostess intercepts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko doesn't manage to read her lips. The hostess, smil awaits an answer. Chieko waits, expectant, for the hostes to repeat herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko nods and points at her group of girlfriends, who a sitting on the barstools next to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hostess smiles another stupid smile and lets Chieko b Further off, her friends spot her and make silly faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko laughs, walks over to them. They are all dressed t same: short skirts, tight t-shirts. Some of them have piercings in their nose, lips and ears. They all exude hormones in their silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko goes to talk to them in sign language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why all the way in the corner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitsu, with a good body, not very tall and with violet highlights in her hair, points at a pair of tables where group of young men are drinking beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko turns around and stares at one of them wearing a M jersey. Their eyes meet. Chieko keeps her eyes on him, an the boy finally turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko nods without taking her eyes off him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko, Mitsu and another of their friends are playing a pinball game that makes noises whenever the ball hits a w The young man in the Milan jersey approaches Chieko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither Chieko, nor her friends answer. The guy turns to look at one of his friends, who signals for him to insist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I play with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko, obviously, cannot hear him. She keeps playing. Suddenly, Mitsu notices the young man's presence and taps Chieko on the shoulder. Chieko turns around and is surpri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man turns to look toward his friends as he spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to come have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko gets frustrated; she cannot read his lips. He stop looking at his friends and awaits an answer, but all he s is three silent girls staring at him stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko talks to Mitsu in sign language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I couldn't read his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man, upon seeing them communicate, is caught of guard. He turns around and walks toward his friends witho saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko leans on the sink while Mitsu pees in one of the stalls. Chieko is noticeably upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitsu walks out of the stall, fixing her skirt.   She see Chieko is distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In sign language) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In sign language) They look at us like we're monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come off it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko is at a loss for words. Mitsu stares at her: it lo like another one of many tantrums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko hikes up her skirt and starts to pull down her pan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they're going to meet the real hairy monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes the gesture of sticking her finger up a hole, t goes to the toilet, throws her panties in and flushes. Sh turns to look at Mitsu defiantly, who cannot help but lau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko sits on one of the restaurant's benches. Before he is a new group of young men. Mitsu and Chieko exchange a look. Provocatively, Chieko crosses her legs slowly revea her pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the young men seems to notice, and is stunned. Chi smiles and does it again. He watches Chieko again and discretely turns to one of his friends to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chieko turns her back to him and faces the bar.    She lo over at Mitsu, who shakes her head, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beeper rings on Chieko's skirt. She picks it up and rea "Don't forget your appointment with the dentist. Papa."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the beeper away and turns toward Mitsu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you later at my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mischievously turns toward the table where the young was, and as she gets off the bench she spreads her legs w open, flashing him shamelessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed and Yussef run full speed, herding their goats as t go. Some of them get left behind and Yussef hurries back them. As they climb a hill, he slips and falls, rolls downhill and drops the rifle, which slides a few meters a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed runs to help him. Yussef gets up, covered in dust a with a scratch on his forehead. Ahmed picks up the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, man, hurry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed runs off, hands flailing, to herd the straggling sh Yussef follows him, limping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers make it back home. Agitated, they put the go back into their corral. Zora walks out and approaches the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef, busy closing the corral gate, pays no attention. Ahmed, breathing agitatedly, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you what's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed, full of adrenaline, glances angrily at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care, whore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef gets in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to her like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef steps up to defend her, but Ahmed spins around and goes into the house. Yussef turns to Zora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something we ate make us sick so we came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without another word, Yussef also goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef and Ahmed are sitting on their mats, looking at ea other, pale, scared and quiet. Yasira walks in to see the followed by her daughters. She turns to Ahmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed, livid, cannot answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something we ate gave us a stomach ache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasira stares harshly at Ahmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is that why you're insulting your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed looks at Zora, then Yussef, and then is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were feeling really ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasira points toward the corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goats are going to feel even worse if they don't eat. Take them out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our stomach really hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then start jerking the meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasira walks out.    Yussef and Zora exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef and Ahmed are jerking a couple of young goats with very sharp knives. They set the thin strips on newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look nervous.    They talk in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you think something happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People were screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent for a long while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef stares at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was both our faults. We both shot. (A beat) Swear to me you'll never say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed won't answer. Yussef looks around the room to make sure nobody is listening to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear.     Nobody, never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed remains pensive.    He sighs and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear.   Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers are hanging the strips of meat on ropes to d them in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old Valiant packed with seven men parks in front of th house and Abdullah gets out. He raises his hand to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver also raises his hand and then drives off.   Ab turns to Yussef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell your mother to prepare dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah turns towards the house. Yussef comes out runnin towards a little field below the house. Yasira is plowing with a manual plow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, mother, father says he wants to have dinner now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah and his children sit at the small table while th women prepare the food. A column of smoke rises from the fire where they are roasting goat meat and toasting bread

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamil, the youngest of the daughters, sets some bread on table. Abdullah takes it, tears some off and starts to ea He turns to Yussef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill any jackals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shot at them, but didn't hit them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to kill them. If not they're going to eat all the goats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasira sets the strips of goat meat on the table. Abdulla serves himself some. His children wait until he's done to serve themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you home so late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah starts talking with his mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They closed the road, and we had to take the long way around. (He swallows) Apparently some terrorists killed an American tourist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahmed and Yussef shoot each other a nervous glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the terrorists attacked a tour bus on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there aren't any terrorists here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdullah finishes his mouthful. He wipes himself with his sleeve. Ahmed doesn't even dare raise his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef, nervous, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you know the American died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they were saying. The police are looking for the culprits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yussef and Ahmed again exchange a furtive glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. An oil lamp in a Nescafe jar lights the house. The family sleeps in the only two rooms in the house. One of them is the parents room, the other the children's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a goat bleating in the darkness. Abdullah's snori Yasira's breathing. The crunching of wood in the night co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither Yussef, nor Ahmed can sleep.   They both look at other, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago's car crosses the border between San Diego and Tijuana. They drive through a green light at the crossing easily entering Mexico without being stopped by three Mex customs officials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Mike stare through the windows, amazed at the world they are entering: other people, other architecture other colors, other noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago turns towards them while he's driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how easy it is to get into paradise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Yes, this is Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom told us Mexico is really dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago turns toward the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Yes, it's full of Mexicans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia and Santiago look at each other and smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive through Tijuana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Debbie continue to gaze awestruck through the windows. Santiago turns to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like popsicles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago pulls over next to some stalls, and the street vendors run out to offer them their products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children eat their popsicles as they walk through the endless aisles of stalls, past the vendors and their ince banter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this flavor called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago answers before Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Spanish) Cajeta... it's called cajeta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mispronouncing) Cayeto...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, cajeta... cajeta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cajeto, cajeta... It's the best thing I've ever tasted in my life. (A beat) Can I buy some for my mom? She's gonna love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car drives out of the city and gets on a highway.   T desert rises in all its magnitude and severity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago parks the car next to a junkyard.   Amelia and D run out and hide behind a fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie pulls her underpants down to pee.   Troubled, she at the mound of destroyed cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they crashed cars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did lots of people die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive down the highway and then turn onto a path. Th drive down the path at high speed, lifting up clouds of d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at a dusty hamlet in the middle of the desert few houses, no more than twenty, some adorned with multicolored paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several crates of soda are stacked up against a makeshift shed built out of yucca fronds. A group of musicians who play NorteГ±a music are setting up their instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are various pickup trucks and smuggled cars parked around the hamlet. The guests are wearing their best: fre shirts, big buckles, almost new boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago parks. Amelia gets out first.     A group of peo sees her and comes over to greet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (All in Spanish) Hey, so you finally made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia smiles.   Her friends notices Mike and Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia nods. Luis (24), Amelia's son, a typical NorteГ±o cowboy with long sideburns and moustache, his face tanned from days under the sun, wearing a pistachio-colored tuxe with a cloth flower in the lapel, greets Amelia with a ki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi mom, how're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you look like Pedro Infante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like Luis Miguel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the bride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not here yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean she's not here yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Debbie, struck dumb by the language and the strangers, hide behind Amelia, who introduces them to Lui

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look son, these are Mike and Debbie, the kids I take care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis holds his hand out ceremoniously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago calls out to some kids who are running around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst.   Lucio, come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucio (10), the oldest of the gang, approaches.   Santiag gestures toward the two American kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are Mike and Debbie. Keep an eye on them for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucio gives them a scornful glance and calls them over ha heartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her hand, Amelia signals to the kids that it's ok to with him. Shyly, Debbie and Mike follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia is in a room with her two daughters standing in fr of a peeling and broken mirror putting on her violet gown One of her daughters helps her and pulls the zipper all t way up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (All in Spanish) Oh ma, I don't know how you did it but it zipped up perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's been 15 years since I last wore this dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't changed a bit, ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working, dear, working, that's what keeps one young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two sisters realize that the dress has a hole just be the seat, exchange looks and smile, which doesn't please Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys laughing about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing ma, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia looks at them suspiciously, turns around and leave the room with her dress elegantly torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is in the middle of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several of the tourists are hiding under their seats, frightened. The driver, still ducking, looks toward the mountains to try to piece together what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard holds Susan against his shoulder, blood gushing f her neck. Her eyes are open and staring at a fading world

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard takes Susan from under her armpits and carefully lays her down on the aisle. Anwar runs over to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy honey, take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar takes his shirt off - left only in his undershirt - and puts it under Susan's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling senselessly) I'm ok... I'm ok...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan breathes in, and every time she does, blood flows f her wound. Richard turns toward the other passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anybody a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody answers.   Richard starts to lose his cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please: a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pensioners don't answer; they are too scared. Richard opens Susan's purse and sees a cell phone. He turns it on and tries to call, but there is no signal. He turns to An

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the nearest hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's far away, about four hours. (a beat) There's a clinic that's a little closer, about an hour and a half to the south. By bus it'll take us about two hours and a half though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that takes away from Marrakesh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but it's the closest thing we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard runs down the aisle and gets out of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cars drive by. The road is almost deserted. In the distance, a run-down Renault approaches. Richard stands i the road to stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car brakes and Richard runs toward the driver: an old peasant traveling with his eight year-old grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help. We were attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) I don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard grows desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help... hospital...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) I don't understand you sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard sees that Anwar and the bus driver have gotten ou of the bus and he starts shouting at them for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him we need his help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the distraction, the old man drives off. Richard wat helplessly as they drive away and he grabs Anwar by the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take her to the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus makes a U-turn and drives away at full speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus rattles along. Richard huddles over Susan, trying stop the blood flowing from her neck. Barth, an old man s shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marrakech isn't this way. They're going to shoot at us again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get her to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to kill us all. Turn back... turn the bus around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard gets exasperated at the old man's screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, god damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barth shuts up and the bus drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus bounces its way down the straight highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers sit quietly. As the ride gets bumpier, Sus starts to cry out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts, it hurts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard tries to calm her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, sweetie, easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts... it hurts so much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard turns her around and sees her shoulder has been shattered. She won't stop shouting. A pool of blood start trickling down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A Anwar) Isn't there anywhere else we can take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can take her to my town. It's near here and there's a doctor. In the meantime we can call Erfourd for an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard turns to look at Susan, who is writhing in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the driver, in Arabic) Make a right onto the next road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Anwar exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus leaves the main road and turns into a dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus' poor suspension gives the passengers a jolt. tries to protect Susan's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls into a small group of houses. Several child run beside the bus, chasing it. Some gaunt dogs get out o the way to let the bus by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up in front of a modest house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard raises his head and sees the desolate environs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, this is my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard tries to carry Susan, but she screams in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, darling, easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips his hands under her and lifts her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard moves his hand, which is covered in blood. As he carries her, he turns into the aisle while Anwar and one the passengers try to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard carries her into the house through a crowd of cur children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar leads Richard down the hallways amidst Susan's scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk through a dusty patio and Anwar points at some stairs. Richard climbs them with difficulty and Anwar ope the door to a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old woman (87), Anwar's grandmother, who has centuries desert in her expression, lets them in and points at a ru on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Put her there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard understands and softly lays Susan on the rug. Sus looks around horrified: adobe walls, dirt floor: the epit of the third world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to call an ambulance and contact my embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have the number of the embassy, I can go call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously, Richard does not have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to make a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get ready to leave and Susan starts imploring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me here alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan looks desperate. To set Richard somewhat at ease, Anwar points at his Grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard leans over Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar kneels down next to her, takes a cloth and improvis a tourniquet that he adjusts near her shoulder. He turns towards the grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Hold and release the tourniquet every once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother nods. She sees the swarm of kids looking into the place and she shoos them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Get out of here... out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids obey, except for one or two who take one last lo before they go. Susan's terrified eyes watch Anwar and Ri leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is still parked in front of the house. As soon as Richard walks out, the pensioners approach him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad. Very bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom (51), a fat English passenger, faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get her outta there and let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where should I take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Egypt, in a town like this, they slit thirty German tourists' throats. They might do the same to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar listens and intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Aggressively) What do you know? We have to get out of here as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly (79), an old woman, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very hot, sir, and the driver turned off the air conditioning. I'm feeling sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James (82), Lilly's husband, steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use in staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case I need the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can go drop us off and then come back for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas (75), a tall old man with good posture, interject

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay with you if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elyse (73), his wife, scolds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why would you stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please wait.     Let me try to deal with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to risk our lives, so hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas looks defiantly at Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what you have to do, we'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Anwar walk down the streets of the small haml before the people's inquisitive gaze. They arrive at a general store with all sorts of roots and grains displaye outside. Anwar walks over to the owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) We need your phone.     I'll pay for the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is lying on the floor, desolate. It seems as if the pain is diminishing. The grandmother leans over her and s caresses her with her dirty, wrinkled hands. This startle Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is a little bit uncomfortable with her this close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have some water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman doesn't seem to understand. She grabs a bas of dates and offers them to her. Susan shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her hand, Susan mimes drinking a glass of water. The old woman seems to understand. She pours some water from jar, leans over her and helps her drink in small sips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother bows her head as if to say "your welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman just smiles. Susan makes a gesture of desperation. The grandmother leans over her, unfurls her index finger and points at her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Trust in god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan keeps looking at her as she slowly gets up and goes sit in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is in a small cubicle dialing on an old cream-col rotary phone while Anwar waits discretely in a corner. Do of people watch from outside. Richard turns to look at th while the call connects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Rachel? It's Richard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ВїAre you still in Moroccco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're still in Morocco...Rachel, there was an accident, your sister was shot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised) What? Who shot her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... We were shot at from some hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was hit in her neck and shoulder. Rachel, she's not doing well... I need you to tell the embassy as soon as possible... wait... and call Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Anwar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar, where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Tazarine, three hours southwest of Erfoud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were in Tazarine, T-a-z-a-r-I-n-e Three hours southwest of Erfoud... in the desert... it's a town... there's no hospital... There's nothing here at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you calling me from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a shop. Rachel, this is urgent... urgent... call the embassy... They have to help us... call James too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did they shoot her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Rachel, you're sister's badly hurt... do you understand? Call for help... now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. As soon as he does, he turns to Anwar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call an ambulance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call Erfoud so they send one over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar, clumsy and stressed at Richard's desperation, take the phone and starts dialing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And find a doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he finishes dialing, Anwar turns to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've already gone to look for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard returns to the room. Susan, weak, lies with her eyes open. The grandmother is tending to the wound, which won't stop bleeding. She gets up and goes to Anwar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Anwar, bring me some water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar goes out to the patio and fetches a metal basin ful of soil. He goes to a well, scoops out some water with a gourd and washes out the basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar is walking back when he is stopped by Mohammed, his brother, a fat man (32) with curly hair and a tanned face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the entire dialogue in Arabic) Why did you bring them here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar doesn't pay attention to him and keeps walking towa the room. His brother catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have consulted with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar stops and looks at him fixedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hurt, we had to take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In town they're saying she was shot by terrorists. Do you know what they're going to do to us when they find out she's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be paranoid and go help find the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar pays no more attention to him and carries the basin into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is lying down. A small pool of blood has collected under her neck. She looks restless. She whispers weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out of here... please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to as soon as I can. I've already called Rachel; she's going to tell the embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we shouldn't have come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Anwar enters. The grandmother takes the basin a sets it in a corner. She gets some pieces of cloth and st to soak them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until the ambulance gets here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour and a half. It's coming from Alnif.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That much? Isn't there anyone here who could take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anwar shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get her out of here. There's no one to tend to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother already called a doctor, he's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is going to say something, but holds back.   His despair and confusion are evident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust my grandmother; she knows a lot about remedies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother wrings out the rags and puts them on a ta She takes some herbs, a fistful of earth from the floor a she tosses them into the basin. She stirs it and pulls ou a clump of mud which she lays out on one of the pieces of cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan looks horrified at the dirt. The grandmother leans over her and tries to clean the wound with the other mois rags. Susan resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) I have to clean you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Susan) Miss, my grandmother is going to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grandmother finishes cleaning her with the damp cloth and grabs the clump of mud. She tries to put it on the wo but Susan flinches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) It will stop the bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... not that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Anwar) Let's wait for the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two old men walk through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mohammed walks into the room and calls him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) The sheik and the moukadem are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men walk past the tourists and head inside withou knocking or asking for permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Anwar have walked out into the patio to wait them. The sheik approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Allah be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Allah be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Richard and speaks to him in very bad French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In bad French) I am Atallah the sheik and this is Walid, the moukadem. I'm very sorry about your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he is very sorry about your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard thanks him with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Anwar, in Arabic) Tell him that I want to ask him some questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Richard) Can he ask you some questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard nods.   The sheik continues in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Do you have any enemies in this country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asks if you have any enemies in this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Then why were you shot at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come to Morocco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) He has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) What does he do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a magazine editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) He edits magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Anti-muslim magazines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anti-muslim magazines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, magazine magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) No, normal magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him we need to get my wife out of here. Ask him if the ambulance is on its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) He wants to get his wife out of here. He wants to know if the ambulance is on its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Arabic) Tell him the federal police are in charge of this, that they are going to send the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says the federal police are already in charge, that they are going to send the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheik looks at the house.
